title: How to Make an Olive Medley

steps.headline: Cook the lamb shanks.
steps.description: Before cooking, cover your lamb shanks in salt and pepper. Make sure to wash your hands before and after touching raw food. From there, heat your olive oil in a large, heavy pan. Make sure it has a lid that fits. Cook the lamb shanks until they're completely brown. Take your time doing this, as it may take awhile. Do not stop cooking until every side of your shanks is brown. Remove the meat and set aside when you're done.

steps.headline: Brown the vegetables.
steps.description: Use the same pan you used to cook the lamb. Add the celery, shallots, and garlic. Cook them in the juices from the lamb until they're golden brown.

steps.headline: Simmer with the meat, liquids, and bay leaves.
steps.description: Once the vegetables are brown, add the meat back to the pan. Pour in the wine and broth, as well as the bouquet garni, and bay leaf. Cover your pan completely. Allow it to simmer over the stove for an hour at medium-low heat.

steps.headline: Add the olives and sun-dried tomatoes and simmer.
steps.description: Once you place the olives and sun-dried tomatoes in the pot, it may be a little dry. If this is the case, pour in a little more wine. Cover the pot again and allow it to simmer for an additional 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Add salt and pepper to taste.
steps.description: Once everything is cooked, the lamb should be falling off the bone. At this point, salt and pepper your medley to taste.

steps.headline: Serve your medley as you desire.
steps.description: You should pull the meat off the bone before serving. This medley can be served as a stew. However, it also works great as a sauce for pasta. Make sure anyone eating knows the olives still contain their pits.

steps.headline: Whisk together the liquids and herbs.
steps.description: In a small mixing bowl, whisk together the olive oil, lemon juice and zest, the herbs de Provence, and the minced garlic cloves. Use a wire whisk or fork to beat everything together until you have a smooth, consistent texture.

steps.headline: Add the olives.
steps.description: Throw the olives into the mixing bowl. Shake the bowl or use a spoon to stir until the olives are evenly coated in the seasoning. It's easier to coat the olives by tossing the bowl slightly. It's a good idea to cover the bowl with plastic wrap first to make sure none of the olives fall onto the floor or counter.

steps.headline: Marinate overnight.
steps.description: Place the bowl in the refrigerator overnight to allow it to marinate. Make sure to cover the bowl first. As it marinates, stir it occasionally. You can serve it the next day. If your medley doesn't get eaten in a single night, it can be stored in the refrigerator up to a week.

steps.headline: Beat the cream cheese with an electric mixer.
steps.description: You want the cream cheese to have a smooth texture. Place the cream cheese in a mixing bowl and use an electric mixer to mix the cream cheese on medium speed until it's smooth.

steps.headline: Stir in the olives, lemon peel, garlic powder, and black pepper.
steps.description: You should use about 1/4 of a cup of black pepper, but you can use more or less depending on taste. Stir all the ingredients together using a mixing spoon until everything is mixed evenly.

steps.headline: Spread the bay leaves, peppers, and olive mixture on each tortilla.
steps.description: Heat your tortillas over the stove or in the microwave, according to the directions on the package. Spread one layer of the cream cheese/olive mixture onto the tortillas. Stack a bay leaf and a pepper on top of the tortilla. Roll the tortillas into a tight cylinder, keeping them parallel with the pepper. You should have about 10 servings when you're done.

steps.headline: Refrigerate for two hours.
steps.description: You should refrigerate your tortillas for about two hours. Wrap each tortilla in plastic individually before refrigerating.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: When you're ready to serve the tortillas, remove them from the refrigerator and unwrap them from the plastic wrap. Trim the edges of each roll so they're even. Then, cut them into 1/2 inch slices.

text: Making Autumn Olive Medley Cook the lamb shanks. Before cooking, cover your lamb shanks in salt and pepper. Make sure to wash your hands before and after touching raw food. From there, heat your olive oil in a large, heavy pan. Make sure it has a lid that fits. Cook the lamb shanks until they're completely brown. Take your time doing this, as it may take awhile. Do not stop cooking until every side of your shanks is brown. Remove the meat and set aside when you're done. Brown the vegetables. Use the same pan you used to cook the lamb. Add the celery, shallots, and garlic. Cook them in the juices from the lamb until they're golden brown. Simmer with the meat, liquids, and bay leaves. Once the vegetables are brown, add the meat back to the pan. Pour in the wine and broth, as well as the bouquet garni, and bay leaf. Cover your pan completely. Allow it to simmer over the stove for an hour at medium-low heat. Add the olives and sun-dried tomatoes and simmer. Once you place the olives and sun-dried tomatoes in the pot, it may be a little dry. If this is the case, pour in a little more wine. Cover the pot again and allow it to simmer for an additional 30 minutes. Add salt and pepper to taste. Once everything is cooked, the lamb should be falling off the bone. At this point, salt and pepper your medley to taste. Serve your medley as you desire. You should pull the meat off the bone before serving. This medley can be served as a stew. However, it also works great as a sauce for pasta. Make sure anyone eating knows the olives still contain their pits. Making Herb-Laced Autumn Medley Whisk together the liquids and herbs. In a small mixing bowl, whisk together the olive oil, lemon juice and zest, the herbs de Provence, and the minced garlic cloves. Use a wire whisk or fork to beat everything together until you have a smooth, consistent texture. Add the olives. Throw the olives into the mixing bowl. Shake the bowl or use a spoon to stir until the olives are evenly coated in the seasoning. It's easier to coat the olives by tossing the bowl slightly. It's a good idea to cover the bowl with plastic wrap first to make sure none of the olives fall onto the floor or counter. Marinate overnight. Place the bowl in the refrigerator overnight to allow it to marinate. Make sure to cover the bowl first. As it marinates, stir it occasionally. You can serve it the next day. If your medley doesn't get eaten in a single night, it can be stored in the refrigerator up to a week. Making Olive Medley Pinwheels Beat the cream cheese with an electric mixer. You want the cream cheese to have a smooth texture. Place the cream cheese in a mixing bowl and use an electric mixer to mix the cream cheese on medium speed until it's smooth. Stir in the olives, lemon peel, garlic powder, and black pepper. You should use about 1/4 of a cup of black pepper, but you can use more or less depending on taste. Stir all the ingredients together using a mixing spoon until everything is mixed evenly. Spread the bay leaves, peppers, and olive mixture on each tortilla. Heat your tortillas over the stove or in the microwave, according to the directions on the package. Spread one layer of the cream cheese/olive mixture onto the tortillas. Stack a bay leaf and a pepper on top of the tortilla. Roll the tortillas into a tight cylinder, keeping them parallel with the pepper. You should have about 10 servings when you're done. Refrigerate for two hours. You should refrigerate your tortillas for about two hours. Wrap each tortilla in plastic individually before refrigerating. Serve. When you're ready to serve the tortillas, remove them from the refrigerator and unwrap them from the plastic wrap. Trim the edges of each roll so they're even. Then, cut them into 1/2 inch slices.
